Action.author: swetharepakula
Action.body: ~kss-espeo Have you instantiated the chaincode in your network?

Action.author: kss-espeo
Action.body: What is the output of `peer chaincode list --installed` Get installed chaincodes on peer: Name: evmcc, Version: 0, Path: github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaincode-evm/evmcc, Id: 855c34d681a554e02102fbc58f7649ec9b1e8056d7949b29a3d4a4679fbdd92c Name: mycc, Version: 1.0, Path: github.com/chaincode/chaincode_example02/go/, Id: 333a19b11063d0ade7be691f9f22c04ad369baba15660f7ae9511fd1a6488209 >and `peer chaincode list --instantiated` ? Get instantiated chaincodes on channel mychannel: Name: evmcc, Version: 0, Path: github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaincode-evm/evmcc, Escc: escc, Vscc: vscc Name: mycc, Version: 1.0, Path: github.com/chaincode/chaincode_example02/go/, Escc: escc, Vscc: vscc >What version of Fabric are you using? Whatever https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-samples/tree/release-1.4/first-network is using, so 1.4.3 I believe. >

Action.author: swetharepakula
Action.body: If you do `docker ps` do you see a container that contains `evmcc` in the title?

Action.author: kss-espeo
Action.body: Are you able to interact with the evmcc using remix? When attempting that I am getting same error message, so: {noformat} Cannot get account list: Error: Failed to query the ledger: Transaction processing for endorser localhost:9051 : Chaincode status Code: (500) UNKNOWN. Description: cannot retrieve package for chaincode evmcc/0, error open /var/hyperledger/production/chaincodes/evmcc.0: no such file or directory{noformat} >Also if you look at the peer logs do you see anything that has more information about the possible error? Not really, log output looks healthy. The only weird log entry I could find is: {noformat} peer0.org1.example.com | 2019-10-08 16:54:23.273 UTC endorser ProcessProposal -> ERRO 160 mychannel 49941072 simulateProposal() resulted in chaincode name:"lscc" response status 500 for txid: 4994107277cc3d5d4cb5c35aad74c872074c1749ab688b89a455bd1a9d301e10{noformat} But I'd imagine this is about my failed interaction attempt with a chaincode. >

Action.author: swetharepakula
Action.body: How many evmcc containers do you see running? If you ran through creating solidity smart contracts using the peer cli you should have at least 2 containers. That leads me to ask did you install the evmcc on every peer? You have to run the install 4 times for the first-network example and instantiate once.

Action.author: kss-espeo
Action.body: How many evmcc containers do you see running? I can see only one evmcc container: {code:java} root@espeo-kspisacki:/home/kspisacki/coding# docker ps -a | grep evmcc 79a453a88590 dev-peer0.org1.example.com-evmcc-0-aaf37d90d8d396f179cf05229debb5f1c9d24e5737db406a2af8112b9f7b7c75 "chaincode -peer.add…" 26 minutes ago Up 26 minutes {code} EVM Chaincode is deployed and instantiated on it, as confirmed by following commands: {code:java} peer chaincode list --installed peer chaincode list --instantiated {code} I deployed EVM chaincode using a following guide: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-chaincode-evm/blob/master/examples/EVM_Smart_Contracts.md >

Action.author: swetharepakula
Action.body: Hi, can you verify that on each peer? So instead of running the commands in the cli container check it in each peer container. My guess is that evmcc is only instantiated on one peer which is the one the cli is configured to talk to. But when you run a transaction, fab3 is choosing a different peer to talk which doesn't have the evmcc installed.
